page.description: CDOW() returns a character string containing the name of the day of the week for the specified Date. If the optional localized flag is true, report the localized day name. (Localized flag requires Version 10.5 or later)

prototypes.prototype: Day_of_Week as C = CDOW(D date[,L localized])
Day_of_Week as C = CDOW( D time as T [, localized as L])

argument.name: date
argument.description: A variable containing a date value or a character string containing a legitimate representation of a date value ( ISDATE (Date_Value) = .T.).

argument.name: time
argument.description: A variable containing a date time value.

argument.name: localized
argument.description: Logical. A variable containing .T. if a localized date is requested.

page.example: cdow(START) -> "Tuesday", if START contains 11/28/95 cdow( ctod( "05/15/95") ) -> "Monday"

section.description: If you print form letters that mention dates in the body of the letter, you may want to create a field containing the day of the week. For example, "I'll see you on Monday" sounds more personal than "I'll see you on 5/15/95." Assume that your table has a date field, APPOINTMNT, which stores the date for a scheduled appointment.
